name: Gougeres
description:
Adapted from Drinking French.

Three things to keep in mind when making these. One is that you should have all the ingredients ready to go before you start. Don’t let the water and butter boil away while you grate the cheese or you’ll lose too much of the water. Second, let the batter cool for a few minutes before adding the eggs so you don’t ‘cook’ them. When you stir in the eggs that you do it vigorously, and without stopping. I’m not a fan of extra dishes to wash, but a stand mixer is the best way to mix the eggs in quickly.

And third, because these are unabashedly loaded with cheese, they won't rise as high as regular cream puffs, but they will get nice and crispy. Just don't expect them to rise to the same heights as standard choux puffs.

Use a strong cheese, such as Gruyere, Comté, Mimolette, sharp cheddar, or a mix of cheeses. You can also add some smoked cheese or a bit of Parmesan to the mix. If you don’t have a pastry bag with a plain tip, you can put the dough into a freezer bag, snip off a corner, and use that. Or simply use a spring-loaded ice cream scoop or two tablespoons to portion and drop the dough onto the baking sheet.
recipeIngredient: 3 tablespoons (40g) butter (salted or unsalted, cut into cubes)
big pinch of chile powder (or a few turns of freshly-ground black pepper)
3/4 cup (about 3 ounces, 90g) grated cheese ((See above for ideas))

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 425ºF (220ºC). Line a baking sheet with parchment paper or a silicone baking mat.
recipeInstructions.name: Preheat the oven to 425ºF (220ºC). Line a baking sheet with parchment paper or a silicone baking mat.

recipeInstructions.text: Heat the water, butter, salt, and pepper in a saucepan until the butter is melted.
recipeInstructions.name: Heat the water, butter, salt, and pepper in a saucepan until the butter is melted.

recipeInstructions.text: Dump in the flour all at once and stir vigorously until the mixture pulls away from the sides into a smooth ball. Remove from heat and let rest two minutes, to cool it down a bit. At this point, you can scrape the dough into the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with the paddle attachment. If you don’t have a mixer, let it cool in the pan, stirring it a few times to let the heat escape.

Remove from heat and let rest two minutes, to cool it down a bit. At this point, you can scrape the dough into the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with the paddle attachment. If you don’t have a mixer, let it cool in the pan, stirring it a few times to let the heat escape.

recipeInstructions.text: Add the eggs, one at a time, stirring quickly to make sure the eggs don’t ‘cook.’ The batter will first appear lumpy, but after a minute or so, it will smooth out. After the eggs have been added, let cool until tepid. (So as not to melt the cheese in the next step.)

recipeInstructions.text: Add about 3/4s of the grated cheese, and stir until well-mixed.
recipeInstructions.name: Add about 3/4s of the grated cheese, and stir until well-mixed.

recipeInstructions.text: Scrape the mixture into a pastry bag fitted with a wide plain tip and pipe the dough into mounds, evenly-spaced apart, making each about the size of a small cherry tomato.
recipeInstructions.name: Scrape the mixture into a pastry bag fitted with a wide plain tip and pipe the dough into mounds, evenly-spaced apart, making each about the size of a small cherry tomato.

recipeInstructions.text: Top each puff with a bit of the remaining cheese, the put the baking sheet in the oven.
recipeInstructions.name: Top each puff with a bit of the remaining cheese, the put the baking sheet in the oven.

recipeInstructions.text: Bake for 5 minutes, then turn the oven down to 375ºF (190ºC) and bake for an additional 20 to 25 minutes, until they’re completely golden brown.
